Situation1: All household chores must be coordinated because relatives are visiting, and the home needs to be fully presentable.
Expectation2: Communicate with pilots to provide instructions and updates
Situation2: Cloud tops are rising quickly, and several pilots await revised climb instructions.
Story: I glance at the clock, my headset pressing into my ear as I scan the radar. The cloud tops are rising faster than forecasted, and three pilots are waiting for my revised climb instructions. My voice must be calm, precise—lives depend on it. But my phone buzzes on the desk, a message from my husband: “Relatives will be here in an hour. Can you help with the living room and set the table?” I picture the chaos at home, the expectation that I’ll share the load, make our home welcoming. My mind splits—one part calculating altitudes and headings, the other tallying chores left undone. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in, the demand to be present and perfect in each. My heart pounds as I try to focus, knowing I can’t be in two places at once, and both are counting on me right now.
